channel.title: Level 300: Incident Response with AWS Console and CLI on AWS Well-Architected Labs
channel.description: Recent content in Level 300: Incident Response with AWS Console and CLI on AWS Well-Architected Labs

item.title: Getting Started
item.description: 1.1 Install the AWS CLI Although instructions in this lab are written for both AWS Management console and AWS CLI, its best to install the AWS CLI on the machine you will be using as you can modify the example commands to run different scenarios easily and across multiple AWS accounts. Install the AWS CLI on macOS Install the AWS CLI on Linux Install the AWS CLI on Windows You will also need jq to parse json from the CLI:

item.title: Identity & Access Management
item.description: 2.1 Investigate AWS CloudTrail As AWS CloudTrail logs API activity for supported services , it provides an audit trail of your AWS account that you can use to track history of an adversary. For example, listing recent access denied attempts in AWS CloudTrail may indicate attempts to escalate privilege unsuccessfully. Note that some services such as Amazon S3 have their own logging, for example read more about Amazon S3 server access logging .

item.title: Amazon VPC
item.description: A Amazon VPC that has VPC Flow Logs enabled captures information about the IP traffic going to and from network interfaces in your Amazon VPC. This log information may help you investigate how Amazon EC2 instances and other resources in your VPC are communicating, and what they are communicating with. You can follow the Automated Deployment of VPC lab for creating a Amazon VPC with Flow Logs enabled. 3.1 Investigate Amazon VPC Flow Logs 3.
